awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jean-Luc Montchamp of the Department of Chemistry at Texas Christian University will explore the development of methods for the formation of compounds that are chiral at the phosphorus atom (P-chiral organophosphorus compounds).  Access to P-chiral compounds remains a major synthetic challenge, and chemists largely still rely on rare commercially available but expensive compounds for the development of their various catalytic methodologies.  This proposal aims at the general and practical preparation of P-chiral phosphorus compounds.  Although a variety of methods exists, to date every single method suffers from significant limitations such as high cost, limited scope and scalability, extended time-investment, or complicated experimental conditions.    
		
Practical routes to P-chiral compounds could have a major impact on enantioselective catalysis, as chiral phosphines are ubiquitous in enantioselective catalysis.   More effective enantioselective catalysis will have an impact in all areas of chemistry where the synthesis of chiral molecules is needed such as the pharmaceutical, agricultural, and chemical industries.  Additionally, this project will provide excellent training of coworkers, from undergraduate research participants to post-doctoral, including those from groups historically underrepresented in the physical sciences.

por.por_cntn:
Organophosphorus compounds are important materials in everyday life: they are used in fertilizers, pesticides, medicines, extractants in mining, and many other applications. The phosphorus atom has four substituents exactly like a carbon atom in other organic compounds. As a result these compounds display chirality (meaning that the compound cannot be superimposed to its mirror image). The only requirement is that no two substituents around the atom are the same. Whereas this property is fundamental in living things and nature, it is also critical for chemists to prepare nature’s building blocks and novel molecules like medicienes. In this project, the goal was to prepare only one of the two possible forms of chiral phosphorus: for example only the left hand or only the right hand. A simple and general method was developed. This problem of preparing chiral phosphorus compounds dates back to at least 50 years ago.  Our approach employs menthol as the source of chirality necessary.  Menthol is one of the least expensive chiral compound. The method that was developed is important because it allows the preparation of building blocks which are themselves employed in industrial processes to prepare other chiral compounds.  Thus, the work is of relevance to industrial chemistry and medicine (most medicines are chiral carbon compounds).  Additionally, the method avoids the use of toxic chemicals, complicated processes such as low temperature and rigorously inert atmosphere, hazardous chemicals like phosphorus trichloride and organometallics, etc.
